DOC.HEAD: Colombians Search for Medellin Drug Boss Escobar
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers searched northern Colombia on Monday for drug lord Pablo Escobar Gaviria, boss of the deadly Medellin cartel. After a four-month war against drug traffickers in which the cocaine gangs have killed at least 200 people, Colombian authorities were heartened Friday by the death of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha in a police shootout near Covenas, on the Caribbean coast. On Sunday, President Virgilio Barco said: ``We will continue our commitment to eradicate narco-trafficking from Colombia. Looking at what happened to Rodriguez Gacha, those involved in this illegal activity will realize what their end will be.'' Rodriguez Gacha, 42, his son Fredy and five bodyguards were killed Friday in the first major government victory of the drug war, which Barco declared after the assassination Aug. 18 of Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, the leading presidential candidate. ``We keep up our search for Escobar Gaviria and other drug traffickers,'' Defense Minister Gen. Oscar Botero told reporters Monday. Officials said a long fight remains. As Barco put it Sunday: ``This war has had a development favorable to the government, but it is not over yet.'' Drug gangs have killed at least 200 people the past four months in bomb attacks in Bogota, Medellin, Cali and other cities. Sixty-three died when a vehicle loaded with explosives exploded this month outside the headquarters of the Colombian Intelligence Police. Security sources said elite military units concentrated their search for Escobar Gaviria on Monday near Cartagena and Sincelejo in northern Colombia, where intelligence reports said he had planned to meet with Rodriguez Gacha. Bogota newspapers said the two had intended to plan sabotage actions to discourage President Bush from attending an anti-drug summit Feb. 15 with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. When asked about the reports, a U.S. Embassy official said: ``We know nothing of it.'' The government has offered a reward equivalent to $580,000 for information leading to the arrest or death of Escobar Gaviria, who is said to have hundreds of men in his own private army. A similar amount was offered for Rodriguez Gacha, who had an army of about 2,000. A diplomat said of Rodriguez Gacha's troops: ``They are mercenaries. Now that their boss is dead, they are probably ... fleeing.'' Escobar Gaviria escaped into the jungle Nov. 22 when police surrounded Cocorna, a town 110 miles from Bogota, where he was hiding. If captured alive, Escobar Gaviria would be extradited to the United States for trial on federal drug smuggling charges. So far 10 Colombians have been extradited to the United States to face drug charges. Colombian drug gangs are believed responsible for 80 percent of the illegal cocaine that enters the United States.
